title: The Folly of the Wicked
shortSummary: Psalm 52 is a prophetic lament by David condemning the deceitful and boastful actions of Doeg the Edomite, who maliciously reported David to King Saul. The psalm contrasts the destructive power of evil speech with the enduring strength and mercy of God, encouraging trust in God rather than in worldly riches.
timeline: c. 1020 BC - Early reign of King Saul, during David's flight from Saul

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The author of the psalm, a future king of Israel, who is the target of Doeg's deceit and who expresses trust in God's mercy.

keyCharacters.name: Doeg the Edomite
keyCharacters.description: A servant of King Saul who maliciously reports David's whereabouts, embodying deceit and wickedness in this psalm.

keyCharacters.name: Saul
keyCharacters.description: The first king of Israel, who is misled by Doeg's false report and pursues David.

definitions.definition: A term meaning 'instruction' or 'contemplation,' indicating the psalm is intended to teach or provide insight.
A liturgical or musical pause in the psalm, inviting reflection on the preceding words.
Speech that is intentionally misleading or false, used here to describe the destructive power of wicked words.
A symbol of vitality and blessing, representing the psalmist's flourishing trust in God's mercy.

outline.heading: Introduction and Condemnation of Doeg's Wickedness
outline.description: David opens by addressing Doeg's boasting in evil and his deceitful tongue, highlighting the destructive nature of his speech and actions.

outline.heading: Description of the Wicked One's Character
outline.description: The psalmist details Doeg's love for evil and lying, pronouncing God's judgment that will uproot him from the land of the living.

outline.heading: The Righteous Contrast and Divine Justice
outline.description: The righteous observe and fear God’s justice, mocking the wicked who trust in riches rather than God’s strength.

outline.heading: The Psalmist's Trust and Praise
outline.description: David declares his steadfast trust in God's mercy and commits to praising God forever, affirming the goodness of waiting on Him.

application: Guard your speech carefully, recognizing the power of words to build up or destroy, and strive to speak truth and righteousness.
Place your trust in God's mercy and strength rather than in material wealth or human power, especially in times of adversity.
Rejoice and praise God continually for His faithfulness and justice, even when facing opposition or false accusations.
Reflect on God's judgment of the wicked as a reminder to live righteously and avoid the path of deceit and evil.

keyVerses.text: Why boastest thou thyself in mischief, O mighty man? the goodness of God endureth continually.
keyVerses.significance: This verse exposes the arrogance of the wicked and affirms the everlasting goodness of God as a foundation for trust.

keyVerses.text: God shall likewise destroy thee for ever, he shall take thee away, and pluck thee out of thy dwelling place, and root thee out of the land of the living. Selah.
keyVerses.significance: It pronounces the sure and eternal judgment of God upon the wicked, emphasizing divine justice.

keyVerses.text: Lo, this is the man that made not God his strength; but trusted in the abundance of his riches, and strengthened himself in his wickedness.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the folly of trusting in wealth and wickedness instead of God’s strength.

keyVerses.text: But I am like a green olive tree in the house of God: I trust in the mercy of God for ever and ever.
keyVerses.significance: It contrasts the psalmist’s confident trust in God’s mercy with the instability of the wicked.
